> Regarding the walker, any advice on improving the fitness function?

Hi C=
olin,
   Have you considered using novelty search for the Bipedal Walker? (=
From Ken Stanley's "Abandoning objectives: evolution through the search for=
 novelty alone" paper, abstract: in "biped walking tasks.. novelty search s=
ignificantly outperforms objective-based search...").

Would Novelty search=
 be easy to add to SharpNeat or would it require significant structural cha=
nges to SharpNEAT to get going? Assuming the use of an existing fast Key/Va=
lue store nosql DB for behaviour storage and KNN lookups, similar to this o=
ne:
http://www.codeproject.com/Articles/316816/RaptorDB-The-Key-Value-Store=
-V2

I only ask as I am curious to try novelty search out for a while on so=
me of the existing SharpNEAT example projects (but as yet have not found th=
e time to look into it).

Regards,
Keith Nelson

> Regarding the walker, any advice on i=
mproving the fitness function?
> This one has stop conditions for when one =
or both of the feet are too
> high, the torso height goes below a threshold=
 or any of the the joint
> angles go beyond 90 degrees. Ideally I'd like to=
 avoid these and make
> it more open ended (and punish for applied torque t=
o get efficient
> walkers) but the reality was that that didn't seem to wor=
k very well.
